title: Setka quits Labor, Albanese claims victory
text:
An angry Mr Setka claimed his decision was personal and was motivated by disdain for Mr Albanese's leadership, including Labor's recent decision to support free trade agreements with Indonesia, Hong Kong and Peru.

“I can no longer stand by and watch Anthony Albanese trash the traditional values of the Labor Party and the union movement.”

“The core values on which the Labor Party was built have been totally eroded under Mr Albanese’s leadership and I cannot support him as a member of the ALP any longer.”

Mr Setka did not complain publicly over the FTA decision until now. Labor sources said Mr Setka quit because he would have been expelled on Friday at a planned meeting by Labor's National Executive.

Mr Setka said he would stay on at the helm of the Victorian division of the CFMEU.

His ouster represents a victory for Mr Albanese whose previous inability to remove Mr Setka was undermining his leadership authority.

Mr Albanese, who initially had Mr Setka suspended but struggled to expel him, said he would always stand up for the rights of trade unions but so, too, would he defend the values of the Labor Party.

Advertisement

"Through his actions he demonstrated values that were not consistent with the values which the Australian Labor Party holds dear,'' Mr Albanese said.

"One of those values is respect for women. The fact he has been convicted of breaching a family violence order and the fact that he was also convicted and pleaded guilty to harassment indicates that that is the case.

"There has also been a range of activity in breach of both the Victorian rules of the ALP and the values of the Australian Labor Party. "

Mr Setka said Mr Albanese’s "betrayal of working Australians" culminated last week with his support for the free trade agreements.

“This is a complete betrayal of working Australians who will lose jobs to foreign workers as a result,” Mr Setka said.

“It was the last straw for me and a sign of just how far out of touch Mr Albanese is with our fundamental principles.”

Mr Setka also accused Mr Albanese of failing to take up the fight on the government’s Ensuring Integrity Bill which will facilitate the deregistration of rouge union officials and unions.

Advertisement

Labor vehemently opposes the bill but independent Senator Jacqui Lambie is threatening to vote for is unless Mr Setka quits the unions. She renewed that threat on Wednesday, saying Mr Setka must quit the union, not just the ALP.

Mr Setka said the bill would "severely restrict workers’ rights to seek fair pay and better working conditions.

He accused Mr Albanese of a smear campaign to oust him that was "based on a lie that he denigrated family violence campaigner Rosie Batty at the national executive meeting''.

“Mr Albanese claims I have brought the ALP into disrepute. Nothing has hurt the Labor Party’s reputation like Mr Albanese’s leadership over the past five months,”

“Enough is enough. I can no longer ignore the effect this is having on my family, along with Anthony Albanese’s betrayal of working Australians and the core values of the Labor Party and Union Movement.”

“Moving forward, I will continue to lead the CFMEU and keep fighting to deliver the best wages, conditions and safety standards for construction workers and their families anywhere in Australia.”

In August, Mr Albanese vowed to continue his pursuit of Mr Setka despite a court ruling the national ALP must defer to its Victorian branch to expel the controversial union boss.

Mr Setka withdrew his appeal to that decision on Wednesday. The ALP National Executive was set to meet Friday to discuss his expulsion.
description: John Setka has resigned as a member of the ALP ending a four-month campaign by Anthony Albanese to have him expelled.
